https://studio.code.org/s/csd7-2021/less.long_instructions:
## Looking for Patterns

Each box on the screen has 3 numbers in them. You can click-and-drag each box to move them around the screen.

Try to group boxes together in any way that makes sense to you. You could compare individual rows of numbers to other boxes, or compare numbers within the box itself - whatever makes sense to you.

# Do This

-   Drag the boxes around the screen so you have at least 3 different groups (you can have more if you'd like!)
-   Once you have your groups, click the "Next" button to reveal what each box represents.
-   Once you've revealed the boxes, see if you can summarize your groups to another person.

# Green Glass Door

In this game, we're trying to learn what words are accepted through the Green Glass Door. See if you can figure out the pattern that determines what words are accepted and what words are rejected.

## Do This

-   Run the app and read the directions
-   Generate at least 5 example words. You can generate more if you'd like - the more examples you have, the more likely you are to figure out the pattern
-   You can try some words yourself to test which words are accepted or rejected. You can use this to verify if you've figured out the pattern.

# Shoe Recommender

This app uses a computer model to help make a decision about what shoes to wear. There are 4 different recommendations the app can make for what shoes to wear.

## Do This

-   Run the app several times. See if you can get each of the 4 recommendations
-   **Make a prediction:** how do you think this app is making its decision?

https://studio.code.org/s/csd7-2021/less.long_instructions: # Fruit & Veggie Explorer This widget has the same fruits and veggies from the previous lesson, but you now have more **features** to play with and more flexibility with how you draw your deciding line. ## How The Widget Works - Hover over a dot to see the food it represents. Orange dots are fruits, purple dots are veggies. - Use the dropdowns to change the features used to create the graph. This will reload your data using your new features. - Click in two places to draw a line to separate the data. - Your accuracy is shown at the bottom. This is how many fruits and veggies landed in the correctly shaded part of the graph. - If you have really low accuracy, try pressing the Flip Colors button to switch the orange vs purple shading - Press the "Try Your Own Food!" button to test your own data and see how your model classifies it. ::: details [**Click Here for Feature Explanations**] - **Size**: How big the food is. The higher the value, the bigger the food is. - **Hardness**: How hard the food is. The higher the value, the harder the food is (usually because of a rind or shell) - **Easy to Eat**: How easy the food is to eat. The higher the value, the easier it is to just pick up the food and eat it - **Juiciness**: How juicy the food is. The higher the value, the juicier the food is. - **Sweetness**: How sweet the food is. The higher the value, the sweeter the food is. - **Can Smell It**: How fragrant the food is. The higher the value, the more the food smells (like onions) - **Green-ness**: How green the food is on the outside. The higher the value, the greener the food is (like watermelon or limes) - **Stackability**: How easy it is to stack the food into a pile. The higher the value, the easier it is to stack the food on one another without them rolling away or squishing. ::: ## Do This Using the dropdowns to adjust the features, draw a line that creates a model that correctly classifies at least 80% of the fruits and 80% of the veggies

https://studio.code.org/s/csd7-2021/less.long_instructions:
This level has dynamic instructions that change as you interact with AI Lab.

-   _The instructions for the **Select Feature** screen say:_ Now you can decide what **features** you want to use to train your model. These are the inputs of your machine learning model - it's where AI Bot will look for patterns to help make its decision. **Do This:** Choose a column to investigate as a potential feature.

    -   _The instructions when you click a categorical feature say:_ When you select a column, additional information appears on the right panel. This can help you decide if this is a useful feature for predicting your label. You can learn more in the Help and Tips section of these instructions. **Do This:** Decide if you would like to use this column as a feature. If so, press the "Add Feature" button. If not, select a new column to explore. Repeat this until you've chosen several columns to use as features.

-   _The instructions for the **Results** screen say:_ On this screen, you can see how accurate AI Bot when comparing its predictions to the testing data that we already know the answers to.  **Do This:** Keep training your model until you have at least 100% accuracy

    -   _The instructions when you click the details panel say:_ This screen shows you the individual rows AI Bot got correct or incorrect. This can help explain why this model earned the accuracy score that it did. You can learn more about how accuracy is calculated in the Help and Tips panel.

# Book Recommender

Run the app and see what kind of books get recommended based on your answers.

# Importing A Machine Learning Model Our model has already been trained - let's import it into App Lab! # Do This - Press the gear icon above the toolbox to open the extra menu, then select _Manage AI Models_ from the list
- Select "Class Book Recommender" from the list, then press the Import button.
- Press the "Run" button and test the app to verify that it works. You do **not** need to edit any of the code! Throughout the unit we'll learn more about what these blocks do, but you don't need to make any changes right now. # With A Partner: - Can you identify the line where the button press happens? - Can you identify the lines where all of our data is being collected? - Can you identify the line where our prediction happens?

# Updating our Text

Lets update our text design elements so they ask a question rather than use the default values. If you don’t remember the exact question, you can go back to the model card to view the description for each feature and label.

# Do This:

-   In the App, go into Design Mode
-   Update the text of each feature to match the question from the survey:
    -   Which animal do you like the most?
    -   Which word best describes you?
    -   Where would you prefer to spend your time?
    -   How would you prefer to spend your time?

When you are finished, continue to the next level

https://studio.code.org/s/csd7-2021/less.long_instructions: # Creating a Home Screen Most apps have a “Welcome” screen when the app first loads, which helps set expectations for the user. In the next few levels, we’ll add a Welcome screen to our app. # Do This: - Go into Design Mode - click the dropdown at the top of the app and select “New Screen” - ::: details [**Show Me How**] ::: - Set the id of this screen to ‘welcomeScreen’ - Press the green "Make Default" button to make sure this is the first screen we see in the app - ::: details [**Show Me How**] ::: - Drag out a Label and type "Class Book Recommender" as the text of the label - Drag out a Label and type a short description of what the app does. - For example: "This app can recommend a book to read based on your interests." - ::: details [**Click Here to see an example of what the welcome screen could look like**] ::: Run the program to make sure it works. It should load the welcome screen, but we haven’t programmed it to continue to the next screen yet. When you are finished, continue to the next level

# Add a Next Icon App Lab has several icons you can use for your apps. Let’s add an arrow icon to our app that we can use to navigate to the next screen # Do This: - **In Design Mode:** - Drag out an Image element - Set the id of this element to ‘nextIcon’ - Next to the ‘image’ property, click the blue Choose link - ::: details [**(Show Me How)**] ::: - In the window that appears, click the Icons tab across the top of the screen - ::: details [**(Show Me How)**] ::: - In the search bar, type "next" to load several icons to choose from - In the middle of the screen are several arrows. Choose one of them to represent our “Next” arrow.
- **In Code Mode:** - Drag out an `onEvent` block - Set the id of the block to "nextIcon" - **Inside the onEvent:** - Drag out a `setScreen` block and select "screen1" from the dropdown menu - ::: details [**(Show Me How)**] ::: Run the program to make sure it works. It should load the welcome screen and, when you click on the arrow, it will load the next screen

ml-intro app lab-book recommender 5A-202.bubble_choice_description: Change the font, color, border, and other properties of your app
ml-intro app lab-book recommender 5A-202.long_instructions:
# Customize Your App

You can continue to customize your app by changing the colors, font, borders, and many other properties of each design element.

# Do This:

- Choose at least 4 elements on your screen to customize
- Choose at least two properties for each element to change. Here are a few suggestions to experiment with:
	- *text color*
    - *background color*
    - *font family*
    - *text alignment*
    - *border width*
    - *border color*
    - *border radius*

When you finish, return to the previous Choice level and select a different challenge

ml-intro app lab-book recommender 5B-202.bubble_choice_description: Add an Image to your Welcome Screen
ml-intro app lab-book recommender 5B-202.long_instructions: # Add an Image Images can make your apps more inviting and appealing to new users. Let's add a new image to the welcome screen. # Do This: - Search for an image that you want to include in your app - Once you find it, right-click on the image and select "Copy Image Address" - ::: details [**(Show Me How)**] ::: - **In Design Mode:** - Drag out an Image element to the screen - In the image property, right-click and select "Paste" from the menu - You can continue to customize the image - resize it to fit how you would like When you finish, return to the previous Choice level and select a different challenge

ml-intro app lab-book recommender 5C-202.bubble_choice_description: Add sounds to your app when the user clicks your buttons!
ml-intro app lab-book recommender 5C-202.long_instructions:
# Play a Sound You can add sounds to your app! Sounds are helpful to let a user know when they've interacted with the screen, like clicking a button. Let's add a sound for when a user clicks one of the buttons on the screen. # Do This: - Drag out a `playSound()` block inside the `onEvent()` block [(Show Me Where)](#triggercallout=event) - In the first blank, click the menu and select "Choose"
- In the menu that pops up, you can find a sound that you like. You can try looking through different categories, or searching for a sound - Try searching for "click" or "app" and see what sounds appear! When you finish, return to the previous Choice level and select a different challenge

ml-intro app lab-book recommender 5D-202.bubble_choice_description: Add a button that lets users visit a library website so they can check out a book
ml-intro app lab-book recommender 5D-202.long_instructions:
# Open a Website

Lets add a button to our predict page that that opens the website to a public library where we can check out the book that was recommended. Here are the steps we'll take to do this:

- Add a button to our predict screen
- Use the [`open`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/open/) block to visit a new webpage

# Do This:

- **In Design Mode:**
	- Drag out a button to the prediction screen
    - Give the button an id of "websiteButton"
    - Change the text of the button to "Visit Library"
- **In Code Mode**
	- Drag out an [`onEvent`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/onEvent/) block
    - Change the id to "websiteButton"
- **Inside the [`onEvent`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/onEvent/)**:
	- Drag out an [`open`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/open/) block
    - Replace "https://code.org" with the website for a library. You may need to search for the web address of your library so you can use it here.

When you finish, return to the previous Choice level and select a different challenge

ml-intro app lab-book recommender 5E-202.bubble_choice_description: Use the playSpeech() block to read text out loud
ml-intro app lab-book recommender 5E-202.long_instructions:
# Read Home Screen Out-Loud

We can use the [`playSpeech`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/playSpeech/) block to read the text on our home page outloud. This is a great way to make our app more accessible for folks with vision impairments.

# Do This:

- Drag out a [`playSpeech`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/playSpeech/) block to the very top of your code [(Show Me Where)](#triggercallout=top)
- In the first blank, type in the text we want to read out loud. It's a good idea to include the name of the app and it's purpose.
- You can customize the block more with the other two options. Choose the gender and language that you prefer.

When you finish, return to the previous Choice level and select a different challenge

https://studio.code.org/s/csd7-2021/less.long_instructions:
## Medical Priority App

A hospital hired a company to create an app to help prioritize patients when they come in.

The app uses a machine learning model that is 80% accurate.

The model was trained on data from 1000 people who entered an emergency room in June 2020.

Our job is to test the app and see how it performs when new people enter the hospital.

## Do This

-   Follow the instructions from your teacher on how to test the app and see how it works

## Abbreviations

-   A - Asian
-   AIAN - American Indian / Alaska Native
-   BAM - Black and African American
-   NHPI - Native Hawaiian / Pacific Island
-   W - White

-   _The instructions for the **Results** screen say:_ **Do This:** Check the accuracy of your model and test a few examples. If you have at least 70% accuracy, press the Continue button. Otherwise, you can try again and keep retraining until you find an accurate model.

    -   _The instructions when you click the details panel say:_ **Do This:** Check the accuracy of your model and test a few examples. If you have at least 70% accuracy, press the Continue button. Otherwise, you can try again and keep retraining until you find an accurate model.

-   _The instructions for the **Model Card** screen say:_ **Do This:** Fill out the Model Card information. The text for the Intended Use and Limitations and Warnings sections are provided on your activity guide. When you're finished, press the Save button.

-   _The instructions for the **Model Summary** screen say:_ We did it! You can see a summary of your model below!

    -   _The instructions when you click a categorical feature say:_ **Do This:** Decide if you would like to use this column as a feature. If so, press the "Add Feature" button. If not, select a new column to explore. Repeat this until you've chosen several columns to use as features.

-   _The instructions for the **Results** screen say:_ **Do This:** Check the accuracy of your model and test a few examples. If you have at least 70% accuracy, press the Continue button. Otherwise, you can try again and keep retraining until you find an accurate model.

    -   _The instructions when you click the details panel say:_ **Do This:** Check the accuracy of your model and test a few examples. If you have at least 70% accuracy, press the Continue button. Otherwise, you can try again and keep retraining until you find an accurate model.

-   _The instructions for the **Model Card** screen say:_ **Do This:** Fill out the Model Card information. The text for the Intended Use and Limitations and Warnings sections are provided on your activity guide. When you're finished, press the Save button.

-   _The instructions for the **Model Summary** screen say:_ We did it! You can see a summary of your model below!

# Pet Recommender

A pet store has created a machine learning model to help recommend a pet to new customers. They’d like us to build an app based on their model. 

# Do This:

-   Click the gear and select “Manage AI Models”
-   Select Pet Recommender from the list and click Import
-   Run the app multiple times to test out the app. Try to get all possible pet recommendations.
    -   _Uhmm.... this app isn't very well organized. It's tough to know what each feature means. Even so: take your best guesses and try different values to see the different pets you can get._

# With a Partner:

-   Some of the features use dropdowns and others use text boxes. What do you think is the difference between these two types of features?

Model Card
[expandable][0]

# Using the Model Card Let’s use the model card to add more information to our app to better describe each label. Using the features and labels section, update each feature so it asks the user a question # Do This: - In the App, go into Design Mode - Update the text of each feature based on the description in the model card - For example: replace "T" with "What is the temperature in your area?" - Update the text for the label based on the description in the model card When you are finished, continue to the next level

[expandable][0]

# A Missing Screen This app has screens for 3 of the 4 pet choices, but it's missing a screen for a Dog recommendation! Let’s use Design Mode to add a new screen for Dogs. ## Do This - Go into Design Mode and add a new screen to your app - Drag out a new Label element to the screen. - In the text property, type "Pet Recommendation: Dog!" into the box - Drag a new Image element onto the screen. - In the image property, copy-and-paste the following image URL into the box: - `https://code.org/images/dog.jpg` - Or: if you want to find your own image of a dog, you can copy-and-paste that image URL into the box - Give the screen, label element, and image element appropriate IDs You won't be able to visit this screen yet. Once you're ready, continue to the next level where we'll add events to our code to make it change screens.

[expandable][0]
Click to expand
# Changing The Screen Let’s use an if-statement to change the screen based on your results. For right now, let’s see if we can get our program to work just for a fish result. ## Do This - Drag out an [`if-statement`(#64B5F6)][1] and place it inside the [`getPrediction`(#d3e965)][2] block ( [Show me where][3] ) - Drag out the [`==`(#FFB74D)][4] block and place it inside the [`if-statement`(#64B5F6)][5] - On the left side of the [`==`(#FFB74D)][6], type `value`. This is the variable that has the result of our prediction. - On the right side of the [`==`(#FFB74D)][7], type `"Fish"`, including the quotes. - Inside the [`if-statement`(#64B5F6)][8] block: - Drag out a [`setScreen()`(#fff176)][9] block and select "fishScreen" from the dropdown menu Test your code! Try to enter possibilites that you think align with a fish and see if you can go to this screen! Once you’ve verified this first screen works, continue to the next level

[expandable][0]
Click to expand
# Completing the App Now that we have all of our screens, lets finish adding if-statements to our program to switch to the correct screen based on the result. ## Do This Repeat the same process we did for the fish screen three more times. As a reminder, here are the steps: - Drag out an [`if-statement`(#64B5F6)][1] and place it inside the [`getPrediction`(#d3e965)][2] block ( [Show me where][3] ) - Drag out the [`==`(#FFB74D)][4] block and place it inside the [`if-statement`(#64B5F6)][5] - On the left side of the [`==`(#FFB74D)][6], type `value`. This is the variable that has the result of our prediction. - On the right side of the [`==`(#FFB74D)][7], type the name of the pet recommendation _including the quotes_. - Remember that you can use the Model Card to remember all the possible prediction values - Inside the [`if-statement`(#64B5F6)][8] block: - Drag out a [`setScreen()`(#fff176)][9] block and select the correct screen from the dropdown menu Test your code! Try to get to each pet! Verify that all of the screens work

# Update the Zoo App

Another student has started creating an app based on Zoo data. They've imported their model and added additional screens, but still need to add updates. Can you help them update their app so it's more descriptive, and so the screens change when pressing the predict button?

## Do This:

-   Use the Model Card to update the text on the Predict Screen
    -   You can access the model card by pressing the gear icon and selecting "Manage AI Models". 
    -   Scroll to the bottom of the model card to see the Label and Feature information
-   Add if-statements inside the [`getPrediction`(#d3e965)][0] block to change the screen based on the predicted animal
    -   You can use the model card to see all of the possible values for the prediction
    -   You will need six if-statements - one for each screen that you want to change to

Let's add a new image to the homepage. # Do This: - Search for an image that you want to include in your app - Once you find it, right-click on the image and select "Copy Image Address" - ::: details [**(Show Me How)**] ::: - **In Design Mode:** - Drag out an Image element to the screen - In the image property, right-click and select "Paste" from the menu - You can continue to customize the image - resize it to fit how you would like When you finish, return to the previous Choice level and select a different challenge

# Play a Sound You can add sounds to your app! Let's see if we can make the app play a certain sound depending on the animal that gets recommended. # Steps: - Use an if-statement to check what animal was selected - Play a sound that matches the animal - Repeat this for each animal # Do This: - Drag out an `if-statement` inside the `getPrediction()` block [(Show Me Where)](#triggercallout=predict) - Drag out a `==` block inside the if-statement. On one side, type *value*. - In the menu that pops up, find a sound that you like. It could sound like a dog, or not - the choice is yours! Repeat these steps for each animal so a different sound plays. When you finish, return to the previous Choice level and select a different challenge

ml-use model card-choice4.long_instructions:
# Open a Website

Once a pet has been recommended, you can help your users visit a pet adoption website to pick out the animal they want. Let's add a button to our predict page that that opens a pet adoption website.

# Steps:

- Add a button to our predict screen
- Use the `open()` block to visit a new webpage

# Do This:

- **In Design Mode:**
	- Drag out a button to the prediction screen
    - Give the button an id of "websiteButton"
    - Change the text of the button to "Get Your Pet"
- **In Code Mode**
	- Drag out an `onEvent()` block
    - Change the id to "websiteButton"
- **Inside the `onEvent()`**:
	- Drag out an `open()` block
    - Replace "https://code.org" with a website of your choice

When you finish, return to the previous Choice level and select a different challenge

ml-use model card-choice5.long_instructions:
# Read Home Screen Out-Loud

We can use the `playSpeech()` block to read the text on our home page outloud. This is a great way to make our app more accessible for folks with vision impairments.

# Do This:

- Drag out a `playSpeech()` block to the very top of your code [(Show Me Where)](#triggercallout=top)
- In the first blank, type in the text we want to read out loud. It's a good idea to include the name of the app and it's purpose.
- You can customize the block more with the other two options. Choose the gender and language that you prefer.

When you finish, return to the previous Choice level and select a different challenge

# Importing Your App

Let’s import the model we just created in AI Lab!

# Do This:

-   Click the gear icon and select “Manage AI Models”
-   Select the model you just saved in AI Lab
-   Run your code and verify that it works
-   Continue to customize your app. For example, you could:
    -   Add a theme
    -   Add a welcome screen
    -   Add images or text
    -   Add information from your model card to other screens on the app

# Raspado Recommender

Update the data variables to use the new design elements on the second screen.

# Do This

-   Drag out a [`getText()`(#fff176)][0] block to each blank to the right of a variable
-   Use the drop-down menu to select the appropriate dropdown
-   Run the app and verify that it works

# Driver Alert System Another way we can improve the user experience for our apps is separating the questions into their own screen. This lets us add more information about each question, and it’s easier for the user to keep track of their answers. This app is used in cars to help alert the driver to dangerous road conditions. When you run the app, you’ll notice that each question appears on its own screen rather than all together. # Do This: - Run this app multiple times. You will see that each question is put on a separate screen rather than all on the same screen. - Pay attention to what design elements are on each screen. # With a Neighbor: - How many features does this app have? What are they? - What is the label for this app? What are the possible outputs?
# Model Card ::: details [Click to view model card] :::

# Deleting the Defaults In order to create our updated app, we need to delete the default elements that were generated when the model was imported. Let's start by deleting these elements and changing the default screen. # Do This: - In Design Mode, click on each element on "screen1" then press the red Delete button. - Select “homeScreen” from the screen dropdown menu. - ::: details [**(Show Me How)**] ::: - Select the screen, then press the "Make Default" button. - Run the app and verify the welcome screen loads. You should also be able to click each “Next” arrow to continue through the screens. You won't be able to see the final screen until we adjust the code for our app in the next few levels. When you are finished continue to the next level
https://studio.code.org/s/csd7-2021/less.teacher_markdown: **Deleting Screen 1:** Another way to accomplish the goals of this level is to delete `screen1` entirely. This has the added effect of deleting all of the elements as well. You can choose to show students how to do this, or let them discover it themselves. In either case: the ultimate goal is to remove the pre-generated elements that are created when you first import a model, so that students can instead work with the newly created UI elements in their app.

This level has dynamic instructions that change as you interact with AI Lab.

-   _The instructions for the **Data Select** screen say:_ **Do This:** Choose a dataset from below that you would like to investigate

    -   _The instructions when you click on a dataset say:_ You can see more information about this dataset on the right panel, including some potential investigations. Once you've found a dataset you like, press the Continue button.

-   _The instructions for the **Select Label** screen say:_ Choose a column you would like to use as your label. This is the output that AI Bot will try to predict. **Do This:** Select a column to use as a label, then press the Continue button.

-   _The instructions for the **Select Feature** screen say:_ Now you can decide what **features** you want to use to train your model. These are the inputs of your machine learning model - it's where AI Bot will look for patterns to help make its decision. **Do This:** Choose a column to investigate as a potential feature.

    -   _The instructions when you click a numerical feature say:_ When you select a column, additional information appears on the right panel. This can help you decide if this is a useful feature for predicting your label. You can learn more in the Help and Tips section. **Do This:** Decide if you would like to use this column as a feature. If so, press the "Add Feature" button. If not, select a new column to explore. Repeat this until you've chosen several columns to use as features.

    -   _The instructions when you click a categorical feature say:_ When you select a column, additional information appears on the right panel. This can help you decide if this is a useful feature for predicting your label. You can learn more in the Help and Tips section. **Do This:** Decide if you would like to use this column as a feature. If so, press the "Add Feature" button. If not, select a new column to explore. Repeat this until you've chosen several columns to use as features.

-   _The instructions for the **Results** screen say:_ On this screen, you can see how accurate AI Bot when comparing its predictions to the testing data that we already know the answers to. You can learn more about accuracy in AI Lab in the Help and Tips section. **Do This:** If you're satisfied with the accuracy of your model, press the Continue button. Otherwise, you can try again and keep retraining until you find an accurate model.

    -   _The instructions when you click the details panel say:_ This screen shows you the individual rows AI Bot got correct or incorrect. This can help explain why this model earned the accuracy score that it did. You can learn more about how accuracy is calculated in the Help and Tips panel.

-   _The instructions for the **Model Card** screen say:_ We can save our model here to use in App Lab later. But first, we need to create our Model Card to help document how our model works. **Do This:** Fill out the Model Card information, then press the Save button.

-   _The instructions for the **Model Summary** screen say:_ We did it! You can see a summary of your model below!

https://studio.code.org/s/csd7-2021/less.long_instructions:
# Importing A Machine Learning Model Our model has already been trained - let's import it into App Lab! # Do This - Press the gear icon above the toolbox to open the extra menu, then select _Manage AI Models_ from the list
- Select "Club Survey" from the list, then press the Import button.
- Press the "Run" button and test the app to verify that it works.

# Updating our Text

Lets update our text design elements so they ask a question rather than use the default values. If you don’t remember the exact question, you can go back to the model card to view the description for each feature and label.

# Do This:

-   In the App, go into Design Mode
-   Update the text of each feature to match the question from the survey
    -   You can use the "Manage AI Models" menu to view the model card if you need to remember the questions from the survey

When you are finished, continue to the next level

# Improving the Style Let’s make the design a little more stylish and appealing to the eyes. We can do this using App Lab’s premade Themes. # Do This: - In Design Mode, click the “Themes” dropdown and select a theme
- Test out different themes until you find one you like. When you are finished, continue to the next level

# Creating a Home Screen Most apps have a “Welcome” screen when the app first loads, which helps set expectations for the user. In the next few levels, we’ll add a Welcome screen to our app. # Do This: - Go into Design Mode - click the dropdown at the top of the app and select “New Screen” - ::: details [**Show Me How**] ::: - Set the id of this screen to ‘welcomeScreen’ - Press the green "Make Default" button to make sure this is the first screen we see in the app - ::: details [**Show Me How**] ::: - Drag out a Label and type "Club Recommender" as the text of the label - Drag out a Label and type a short description of what the app does. You can use the Intended Use and Limitations section of the model card for ideas of what to include here. Run the program to make sure it works. It should load the welcome screen, but we haven’t programmed it to continue to the next screen yet. When you are finished, continue to the next level

# Add a Next Icon App Lab has several icons you can use for your apps. Let’s add an arrow icon to our app that we can use to navigate to the next screen # Do This: - **In Design Mode:** - Drag out an Image element - Set the id of this element to ‘nextIcon’ - Next to the ‘image’ property, click the blue Choose link - ::: details [**(Show Me How)**] ::: - In the window that appears, click the Icons tab across the top of the screen - ::: details [**(Show Me How)**] ::: - In the search bar, type "next" to load several icons to choose from - In the middle of the screen are several arrows. Choose one of them to represent our “Next” arrow.
- **In Code Mode:** - Drag out an `onEvent` block - Set the id of the block to "nextIcon" - **Inside the onEvent:** - Drag out a `setScreen` block and select "screen1" from the dropdown menu - ::: details [**(Show Me How)**] ::: Run the program to make sure it works. It should load the welcome screen and, when you click on the arrow, it will load the next screen

ml-club app-choice accessible.bubble_choice_description: Zoey wants to help make the app accessible so people with disabilities will have an easier time using the app.
ml-club app-choice accessible.long_instructions:
# Make your app more accessible

Zoey wants to help make the app more accessible to folks with disabilities. She wants to use [this website with different design tips](https://github.com/UKHomeOffice/posters/blob/master/accessibility/dos-donts/posters_en-UK/accessibility-posters-set.pdf) to update the look of the app.

# Do This:

- Choose _one_ of the posters from [this link](https://github.com/UKHomeOffice/posters/blob/master/accessibility/dos-donts/posters_en-UK/accessibility-posters-set.pdf) to focus on.
- Follow the guidelines on the poster to update your app. This may include some of the following:
	- Changing the layout of your app, especially how text and images appear on the screen
    - Changing the colors and font sizes to be easier to read
    - Adding more design elements to make each screen clearer
    - Adding a `playSpeech` block to help users with visual impairments
    - Adding an `open` block to include links to additional resources

When you finish, continue to the next level to review your app.

ml-club app-choice features.bubble_choice_description: Isaac and Hawa want to add new screens for each question, rather than having all the questions be on the same Predict screen.
ml-club app-choice features.long_instructions:
# Add More Feature Screens

Isaac and Hawa want to make each question it's own screen so they can add more information about each feature and images. This means the user would start on the home screen, then click through several screens with questions, and then finish on the predict screen.

# Do This:

- In Design Mode:
	- Create a new screen for one of your features. Give it a unique ID.
    - Add a Label element to the screen describing what the feature is Give it a unique ID.
    - Add a Dropdown element to the screen. Give it a unique ID, then use the model card to enter in the choices for the feature.
    - Add a Button element to the screen so the user can click forward to new screens. Give it a unique ID.
    - Once the screen is ready, delete the original design element from the Predict screen.
- Repeat this process for each feature. You should have 4 new screens when you are done
- In The Code:
	- Add an [`onEvent()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/onEvent/) block for each button you added.
    - Inside each [`onEvent()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/onEvent/): Use a [`setScreen()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setScreen/) block to change to the next screen.
    - Update the [`addPair()`(#BB77C7)](/docs/applab/addPair/) blocks to use the new design elements you added to each screen.

When you finish, continue to the next level to review your app.

ml-club app-choice if-statements.bubble_choice_description: Kim and Nico want to add new screens with images depending on what club the user gets recommended
ml-club app-choice if-statements.long_instructions:
# Create Unique Prediction Screens

Kim and Nico want to make it so the user goes to a new screen depending on the recommended club that they get. This means once the user presses the Predict button, they'll be taken to a different screen depending on what their recommendation was.

# Do This:

- In Design Mode:
	- Create a new screen for one of the club recommendations. Give it a unique ID.
    - Add a Label element to the screen describing the club. Give it a unique ID.
    - Add an image to the screen representing the club. Give it a unique ID.
    - Add a Button element to the screen so the user can click to go back to the home screen. Give it a unique ID.
- Repeat this process for each club. You should have 5 new screens when you are done
- In The Code:
	- Inside the [`onEvent()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/onEvent/) block: add an [`if-statement`(#64B5F6)](/docs/applab/ifBlock/) to check the result of the `value` variable.
    - Inside the [`if-statement`(#64B5F6)](/docs/applab/ifBlock/): use a [`setScreen()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setScreen/) block to change the screen depending on what the value was.
    - Add an [`onEvent()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/onEvent/) for the home button you created on this club's new screen
    - Inside the [`onEvent()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/onEvent/): use a [`setScreen()`(#fff176)](/docs/applab/setScreen/) block to return to the welcome screen of the app.
- Repeat this process for each of the clubs

When you finish, continue to the next level to review your app.

# Create Your App!

Import your model and create your app! Follow the guidelines in the project rubric. At the very least, your model must have:

-   A welcome screen
-   Descriptive text for the features
-   A theme

Additionally, you might decide to add:

-   Screens with more information about your app, such as the intended use and limitations
-   Different screens depending on what the app predicts
-   Images and sounds to make your app more engaging
-   Links to external resources or websites related to your app
-   Different screens for each feature, with more information about the data your app is collecting
